summary: In this 1932 West African Court of Appeal case from Ghana, the plaintiffs—siblings of the defendant Samuel Quarshie Nelson—sued for an account of estate proceeds following the government's 1923 acquisition of land formerly belonging to their deceased father, George Akotey Nelson. The deceased had made a deathbed request (recognized as 'samansiw' in Ga Customary Law) that the literate defendant manage the estate for his siblings' benefit. However, under Native Customary Law, the head of the family was not the son but the maternal nephew, Acquah, who confirmed the defendant’s caretaker role. The court held that the defendant, acting as a fiduciary and not as head of family, was liable to account for the compensation he claimed and received (£1,650). The appeal was dismissed with costs, affirming the lower tribunals’ rulings that the defendant must render an account to his siblings.
verdict: Appeal dismissed with costs. Defendant liable to account for estate compensation as fiduciary caretaker, not head of family.
rationaleHighlights: Defendant not head of family under customary law; thus liable to account.
Headship passed to maternal nephew (Acquah), not son.
Defendant acted as fiduciary caretaker per deceased's and family head's request.
Death bed dispositions (samansiw) respected due to affection/respect, not legal will.
Action for account valid against caretaker, not against head of family.
Compensation received by defendant required equitable distribution.
Native Tribunal properly examined accounts; findings upheld.
